comment.author: 14472354@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Australian Postcode and Geotagging Group, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content:
yes, great shot. The Hotel Australia was a fabulous highrise. In 1891, its 56m high dome was highest roof of a skyscraper in Australia!
Its 65m spire dominated the skyline with its arc light shining brightly at night.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ agrippinamajor - Dymocks (see notes) is variously described as originally in Market St - www.dymocks.com.au/contentstatic/corporate/about.asp , and in "an upstairs room in Pitt Street" - books.google.com.au/books?id=puhU4dkyY5gC&pg=PA99&... , moving to the Royal Hotel premises in 1890. The sign looks like it has an arrow beneath the text. Thus thickeneth the plot!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Now that the later 19th century issues of the SMH have been digitised it's now relatively easy to establish where William Dymock's stores were located in the 1880s and 1890s...throughout this period I gather he had the one bookshop which he relocated several times...I haven't yet found any newspaper items which might shed more light on Dymock's initial location(s)...but by late 1883 he had a bookshop at 243 Pitt St (notice 4th from bottom, column 5) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13557287 ; the first store actually known as 'Dymock's Book Arcade' appears to have been at 208 Pitt St from ca. mid 1884 - March 1887... ??? though this pic from late 1884 makes me wonder - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5787315 ; the 142 King St store opened in April 1887 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13630484 and I gather it would have closed at about the time the 428 George St store opened in November 1890 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13799352 ; this advert suggests the 142 King St store was closed following the move to 428 George St (column 3, first item in H.E. Vaughan & Son's advert) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28269824 ; I gather the advert for Dymock's Book Arcade we see here is on the side of 142 King St...of course the advert isn't much help in dating the photo...you'd like to think it was only up during the period that Dymock's Book Arcade was at 142 King St (April 1887-November 1890), but we can't assume this was the case. Per this item the roof of the Australia Hotel was being put on in ?April-May 1890 ('Political and Social Letter', 5th para) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article61231717 ...luckily the building dodged the great October 1890 fire - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13786798 ; here's a description of the hotel written shortly before it opened - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13828879 ; here's a report on the official opening in July 1891 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13830968 Alexander Deane & Sons had their town office and workshops at 32 Castlereagh St...maybe from about 1889-1890...they moved to 42 and 42A Castlereagh St in July 1895 (notice of removal towards bottom of column 4) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13988806 ; Deane & Sons built a number of significant 19th century Sydney buildings...they also built a number of public buildings in country NSW, railway stations, etc. Alexander Dean was also at one point a director of the Waygood Elevator Company, which evidently supplied and maintained lifts for a number of buildings in Sydney and in the other colonial capitals. Per this item the Waygood Elevator Co supplied the lift for the Australia Hotel (see advert top of column 2) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13846121 ; Deane was at one point also a Sydney city councillor. All up I'd say there's a good chance that this pic might have been taken between April/May 1890 (roof put on the Australia Hotel) and November 1890 (Dymock's moved out of 142 King St)...work in progress

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's a pic of the European Hotel in Castlereagh St - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... ; and Kerry's more flattering pic of the Australia Hotel - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3042605328/

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: UPDATE - this pic indicates that Dymock's sign remained up on the building at the corner of King and Castlereagh Sts until at least July/August 1891. [??? for some reason I didn't include the link!] This T&CJ item indicates that the restoration work at St James church was about to start in late June 1893 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64033707 ; This SM item suggests that the restoration work on St James spire began in ca. mid 1894 - news.google.com/newspapers?id=0DNVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4pQDA... Plus as has been pointed out on another pic of the Australia Hotel, the chimney looks to have had some use here...more than just a few months... So to update my previous confident pronouncement: I'd say there's a good chance we're looking at April/May 1890 - mid 1894 (!)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Great work! Henry King also took a series of photos "from the GPO" - plainly they are from the Australia Hotel. Photographed at some date between 1893 (Garden Island sheerlegs) and 1895 (lack of dome on Colonial Sectretary's Building). Not yet on Flickr, they are great to compare with this photo. From west to south clockwise - from.ph/30551 from.ph/30552 from.ph/30553 from.ph/30547 from.ph/30548 (best for comparison with this photo) from.ph/30549

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] These Henry King pics are superb! The first one gives a fantastic view of the Moore St - Martin Place development. Note Lawler's George St Emporium (burned down in September 1894) appears in the last pic. In the comparison pic it's interesting to see that the Dymock's sign is still on the side of what I gather is 142 King St.

The first pic shows the Australia Hotel's chimney in the foreground...just going on the elevation it looks as if the pic would have been taken from the platform above the dome.

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: yes those pics taken from top of dome which was 182ft huigh. the tallest bldg in Australia at the time.great views.
